text: if you've been asked to film a video for
the American Chemical Society the first
thing to do is obtain a lavalier
microphone like this which can be
purchased for about twenty dollars of
Amazon the next thing to do is plug the
microphone into a camcorder and have a
colleague stand up on a chair or a stool
filming you from a downward angle
sometimes they call this a myspace angle
the next thing to do is to introduce
what you're working on or what you work
with don't introduce yourself first so
in this case I might say this instrument
behind me is a automated chromatography
system it's used to purify the natural
products that our laboratory synthesizes
our laboratory is interested in carbon
nitrogen bond formation reactions and to
do that we use ruthenium based catalysts
we like ruthenium because it allows us
to do reactions in one step at room
temperature in a wide variety of
inexpensive solvents so that's the sort
of thing that you might say the other
option is to introduce a problem first
natural products such as toxins from
algae are very hard to synthesize we're
interested in meeting this challenge
using ruthenium catalysts which can
operate in a wide variety of inexpensive
solvents and can do reactions at room
temperature at atmospheric pressure so
those are two possible formats once
you've run out of things to say the
final thing to do is to introduce
yourself the total length of the video
should be between 90 seconds and four
minutes when you're done just saying
your name and your affiliation I'm Erin
row from the american chemical society
you may say i'm joe smith from the
university of delaware
